page.title: 17Changing attitudes
page.content: At the beginning of the 20th century Widmerpool was a "typical" village with a close community spirit. There was the large Hall with its estate providing employment, the Church, about 12 farms, village industries, a school, a shop and a range of social classes with housing which varied accordingly. During the last 30 years Widmerpool has become a wealthy "commuter" village. The Hall was sold to the A.A., so the old ties between the Hall family and the villagers were broken. The farms have become larger but far fewer in number. The most striking difference is in the housing, which is now very middle class owner occupied. The older village families have declined and the influx of new people who have either retired to or want a home in the country has been detrimental to community life.
